00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 contextScientificNotation.pl - Allows entry of scientific notation.
00020 
00021 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00022 
00023 This file implements a context in which students can enter
00024 answers in scientific notation.  It tries hard to report
00025 useful error messages when the student's answer is not
00026 in the proper format, and it also allows you to control
00027 how many decimal digits they are allowed/required to
00028 enter, and how many the system will display.
00029 
00030 This probably should be called LimitedScientificNotation
00031 since it does not allow any operations other than the ones
00032 needed in Scientific notation.  In the future it may be
00033 renamed if we produce a computational scientific notation
00034 context.
00035 
00036 To use this context, add
00037 
00038     loadMacros("contextScientificNotation.pl");
00039 
00040 to the top of your problem file, and then use
00041 
00042     Context("ScientificNotation");
00043 
00044 to select the context and make it active.  You can create
00045 values in scientific notation in two ways:
00046 
00047     $n1 = Compute("1.23 x 10^3");
00048 
00049 or
00050 
00051     $n2 = ScientificNotation(1.23 * 10**3);
00052 
00053 (or even $n2 = ScientificNotation(1230), and it will be converted).
00054 
00055 You can control how many digits are displayed by setting the
00056 snDigits flag in the context.  For example,
00057 
00058     Context()->flags->set(snDigits=>2);
00059 
00060 sets the context to display at most 2 digits.  The default is 6.
00061 By default, trailing zeros are removed, but you can ask that
00062 they be retained by issuing the command
00063 
00064     Context()->flags->set(snTrimZeros=>0);
00065 
00066 It is also possible to specify how many decimal digits the
00067 student must enter.  For example,
00068 
00069     Context()->flags->set(snMinDigits=>3);
00070 
00071 would require the student to enter at least 3 digits past
00072 the decimal place (for a total of 4 significant digits,
00073 including the one to the left of the decimal).  The default
00074 is 1 digit beyond the decimal.  A value of 0 means that
00075 a decimal point and decimal values is optional.
00076 
00077 Similarly,
00078 
00079     Context()->flags->set(snMaxDigits=>6);
00080 
00081 sets the maximum number to 6, so the student can't enter
00082 more than that.  Setting this to 0 means no decimal places
00083 are allowed, effectively meaning students can only enter
00084 the numbers 0 through 9 (times a power of 10).  Setting
00085 this to a negative number means that there is no upper
00086 limit on the number of digits the student may enter (this
00087 is the default).
00088 
00089 As an example, in order to force a fixed precision of
00090 three digits of precision, use
00091 
00092     Context()->flags->set(
00093         snDigits => 3,
00094         snTrimZeros => 0,
00095         snMinDigits => 3,
00096         snMaxDigits => 3,
00097     );
00098 
00099 Note that if you restrict the number of digits, you may
00100 need to adjust the tolerance values since the student
00101 may not be allowed to enter a more precise answer.  In
00102 the example above, it would be appropriate to set the
00103 tolerance to .0001 and the tolType to "relative" in
00104 order to require the answers to be correct to the three
00105 digits that are shown.
00106 
00107 =cut
00108 
00109 loadMacros("MathObjects.pl");
00110 
00111 sub _contextScientificNotation_init {ScientificNotation::Init()}
00112 
00113 package ScientificNotation;
00114 
00115 #
00116 #  Creates and initializes the ScientificNotation context
00117 #
00118 sub Init {
00119   #
00120   #  Create the Scientific Notation context
00121   #
00122   my $context = $main::context{ScientificNotation} = Parser::Context->getCopy("Numeric");
00123   $context->{name} = "ScientificNotation";
00124 
00125   #
00126   #  Make numbers include the leading + or - and not allow E notation
00127   #
00128   $context->{pattern}{number} = '[-+]?(?:\d+(?:\.\d*)?|\.\d+)';
00129 
00130   #
00131   #  Remove all the stuff we don't need
00132   #
00133   $context->variables->clear;
00134   $context->constants->clear;
00135   $context->parens->clear;
00136   $context->operators->clear;
00137   $context->functions->clear;
00138   $context->strings->clear;
00139 
00140   #
00141   #  Only allow  x  and  ^  operators
00142   #
00143   $context->operators->add(
00144      'x' => {precedence => 3, associativity => 'left', type => 'bin',
00145              string => 'x', TeX => '\times ', perl => '*',
00146              class => 'ScientificNotation::BOP::x'},
00147 
00148      '^' => {precedence => 7, associativity => 'right', type => 'bin',
00149              string => '^', perl => '**',
00150              class => 'ScientificNotation::BOP::power'},
00151 
00152      '**'=> {precedence => 7, associativity => 'right', type => 'bin',
00153              string => '^', perl => '**',
00154              class => 'ScientificNotation::BOP::power'}
00155   );
00156 
00157   #
00158   #  Don't reduce constant values (so 10^2 won't be replaced by 100)
00159   #
00160   $context->flags->set(reduceConstants => 0);
00161   #
00162   #  Flags controlling input and output
00163   #
00164   $context->flags->set(
00165     snDigits => 6,     # number of decimal digits in mantissa for output
00166     snTrimZeros => 1,  # 1 means remove trailing 0's, 0 means leave them
00167     snMinDigits => 1,  # minimum number of decimal digits to require in student input
00168                        #  (0 means no decimal is required)
00169     snMaxDigits => -1, # maximum number of decimals allowed in student input
00170                        #  (negative means no limit)
00171   );
00172 
00173   #
00174   #  Better error message for this case
00175   #
00176   $context->{error}{msg}{"Unexpected character '%s'"} = "'%s' is not allowed in scientific notation";
00177 
00178   #
00179   #  Hook into the Value package lookup mechanism
00180   #
00181   $context->{value}{ScientificNotation} = 'ScientificNotation::Real';
00182   $context->{value}{"Real()"} = 'ScientificNotation::Real';
00183 
00184   #
00185   #  Create the constructor function
00186   #
00187   main::PG_restricted_eval('sub ScientificNotation {Value->Package("ScientificNotation")->new(@_)}');
00188 }
00189

00191 ##################################################
00192 #
00193 #  The Scientific Notation multiplication operator
00194 #
00195 package ScientificNotation::BOP::x;
00196 our @ISA = qw(Parser::BOP);
00197 
00198 #
00199 #  Check that the operand types are compatible, and give
00200 #  approrpiate error messages if not.  (We have to work
00201 #  hard to make a good message about the number of
00202 #  decimal digits required.)
00203 #
00204 sub _check {
00205   my $self = shift;
00206   my ($lop,$rop) = ($self->{lop},$self->{rop});
00207   my ($m,$M) = ($self->context->flag("snMinDigits"),$self->context->flag("snMaxDigits"));
00208   $M = $m if $M >= 0 && $M < $m;
00209   my $repeat = ($M < 0 ? "{$m,}" : "{$m,$M}");
00210   my ($digits,$zeros) = ("\\.\\d$repeat","\\.0$repeat");
00211   my $zero = ($m == 0 ? ($M > 0 ? "0.0" : "0") : "0.".("0"x$m));
00212   my $decimals = ($m == $M ? ($m == 0 ? "no digits" : "exactly $m digit".($m == 1 ? "" : "s")) :
00213                  ($M < 0 ?   ($m == 0 ? "" : "at least $m digit".($m == 1 ? "" : "s")) :
00214                              ($m == 0 ? "at most $M digit".($M == 1 ? "" : "s") :
00215                                         "between $m and $M digits")));
00216   $decimals = " and ".$decimals." after it" if $decimals;
00217   $digits = "($digits)?", $zeros = "($zeros)?" if $m == 0;
00218   $self->Error("You must use a power of 10 to the right of 'x' in scientific notation") unless $rop->{isPowerOf10};
00219   $self->Error("You must use a number to the left of 'x' in scientific notation") unless $lop->type eq 'Number';
00220   $self->Error("The number to the left of 'x' must be %s, or have a single, non-zero digit before the decimal%s",
00221                $zero,$decimals) unless $lop->{value_string} =~ m/^[-+]?([1-9]${digits}|0${zeros})$/;
00222   $self->{type} = $Value::type{Number};
00223   $self->{isScientificNotation} = 1;  # mark it so we can tell later on
00224 }
00225 
00226 #
00227 #  Perform the multiplication and return a ScientificNotation object
00228 #
00229 sub _eval {
00230   my ($self,$a,$b) = @_;
00231   $self->Package("ScientificNotation")->make($self->context,$a*$b);
00232 }
00233 
00234 #
00235 #  Use the ScientificNotation MathObject to produce the output formats
00236 #  (if other operators are added back into the context, these will
00237 #   need to be modified to include parens at the appropriate times)
00238 #
00239 sub string {(shift)->eval->string}
00240 sub TeX    {(shift)->eval->TeX}
00241 sub perl   {(shift)->eval->perl}
00242 
00243 ##################################################
00244 #
00245 #  Scientific Notation exponentiation operator
00246 #
00247 package ScientificNotation::BOP::power;
00248 our @ISA = qw(Parser::BOP::power);  # inherit from standard power (TeX method in particular)
00249 
00250 #
00251 #  Check that the operand types are compatible and
00252 #  produce appropriate errors if not
00253 #
00254 sub _check {
00255   my $self = shift;
00256   my ($lop,$rop) = ($self->{lop},$self->{rop});
00257   $self->Error("The base can not have decimal places in scientific notation")
00258     if $lop->{value} == 10 && $lop->{value_string} =~ m/\./;
00259   $self->Error("You must use a power of 10 in scientific notation")
00260     unless $lop->{value_string} eq "10";
00261   $self->Error("The expondent must be an integer in scientific notation")
00262     unless $rop->{value_string} =~ m/^[-+]?\d+$/;
00263   $self->{type} = $Value::type{Number};
00264   $self->{isPowerOf10} = 1;  # mark it so BOP::x above can recognize it
00265 }
00266 
00267 #####################################
00268 #
00269 #  A subclass of Real that handles scientific notation
00270 #
00271 package ScientificNotation::Real;
00272 our @ISA = ("Value::Real");
00273 
00274 #
00275 #  Override these so we can mark ourselves as scientific notation
00276 #
00277 sub new {
00278   my $self = (shift)->SUPER::new(@_);
00279   $self->{isValue} = $self->{isScientificNotation} = 1;
00280   return $self;
00281 }
00282 
00283 sub make {
00284   my $self = (shift)->SUPER::make(@_);
00285   $self->{isValue} = $self->{isScientificNotation} = 1;
00286   return $self;
00287 }
00288 
00289 #
00290 #  Stringify using x notation not E,
00291 #  using the right number of digits, and trimming
00292 #  if requested.
00293 #
00294 sub string {
00295   my $self = shift;
00296   my $digits = $self->getFlag("snDigits");
00297   my $trim = ($self->getFlag("snTrimZeros") ? '0*' : '');
00298   my $r = main::spf($self->value,"%.${digits}e");
00299   $r =~ s/(\d)${trim}e\+?(-?)0*(\d)/$1 x 10^$2$3/i;
00300   return $r;
00301 }
00302 
00303 #
00304 #  Convert x notation to TeX form
00305 #
00306 sub TeX {
00307   my $r = (shift)->string;
00308   $r =~ s/x/\\times /;
00309   $r =~ s/\^(.*)/^{$1}/;
00310   return $r;
00311 }
00312 
00313 #
00314 #  What to call us in error messages
00315 #
00316 sub cmp_class {"Scientific Notation"}
00317 
00318 #
00319 #  Only match against strings and Scientific Notation
00320 #
00321 sub typeMatch {
00322   my $self = shift; my $other = shift; my $ans = shift;
00323   return $other->{isScientificNotation};
00324 }
